Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the "Midwest Several Complex Variables Conference," to be held at the University of Toledo from May 13 to May 15, 2016.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the fields of several complex variables, Cauchy-Riemann geometry, d-bar theory, and other related topics. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. The award gives early career researchers, researchers who are members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF a chance to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: https://sites.google.com/a/umich.edu/mw-scv-16/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Midwest Several Complex Variables Conference was held at the University of Toledo from 13th to 15th May, 2016.

The Midwest Several Complex Variables Conference series started back in 1980's and has significant impact in the field. It provides a unique opportunity for senior and junior researchers to interact and initiate joint projects. Although the conference series successfully continued in every other year, there had been an interruption in the last 5 years. Additionally, this was the first time the conference held at University of Toledo in Toledo, Ohio and the impact of such a crucial conference at Toledo was be another benefit.

The conference featured 8 senior speakers (including 2 women), 11 junior speakers (including 5 women), a lecture series, and a problem session. Most of the funds obtained from NSF were used to support junior researchers in their early career, female mathematicians, as well as graduate students. The non-supported participants had other means of financial support.

The organizers contacted many researchers in the Midwest and beyond and used  social media to encourage young mathematicians to attend  the meeting. The conference was attended by 88 people (of which 79 were  U.S. based mathematicians). The conference also gained international attention, and  participants from the following countries attended the meeting: Austria,  Canada, India, Japan, Norway, Poland and Qatar.

A website containing all the information about the conference was created (see https://sites.google.com/a/umich.edu/mw-scv-16/) and the list of open problems has been uploaded on the website. The Department of Mathematics at the University of Toledo provided facilities and staff. During the conference the announcement for the next conference has been made. Overall we believe that the conference was a success.
